media.def: a disorder marked by progressive enlargement of the head, face, hands, and feet, due to excessive secretion of growth hormone after puberty.
abrupt in onset.
a change in a posted account.
microorganism that requires oxygen to live and reproduce.
body temperature not elevated above normal.
carrying impulses towards the center.
clumping of cells due to the presence of antibodies called agglutinins.
any substance that causes manifestations of an allergy, usually a protein to which the body has built antibodies.
acquired abnormal response to a substance (allergen) that does not ordinarily cause a reaction.
baldness.
an option or substitute to the standard medical treatment plan, e.g. herbal therapies, acupuncture, hypnosis.
the structure in the lung fields through which oxygen and carbon dioxide diffuse during the respiratory process.
condition of not menstruating, without menses.
puncture of the amniotic sac in order to remove fluid for testing.
small glass container that must be broken at the neck to aspirate the solution into the syringe.
the constructive phase of metabolism, when smaller molecules are converted to large ones.
bacterium that does not require oxygen for growth and reproduction.
severe allergic reaction that may result in death.
the study of the structure of the body.
local dilation in a blood vessel wall.
a substance occurring in the blood that works with renin to affect the blood pressure, usually increasing the pressure by vasoconstriction.
blood abnormality in which red blood cells are not equal in size (aniso ? unequal).
loss of appetite.
condition of not ovulating.
a drug that inhibits or destroys pathogenic microorganisms.
A chemical compound introduced to the blood or blood sample to prevent clotting.
protein markers on cells that cause formation of antibodies and react specifically with those antibodies.
medication that opposes the action of a histamine.
any substance that inhibits the growth of bacteria; used on skin before any procedure that breaks the integumentary barrier.
failure of the kidneys to produce urine.
the absence of respirations.
bring tissue surfaces as close as possible to their original positions.
weblike membrane covering the brain and spinal cord.
a small arterial branch that joins a capillary to an artery.
examination of the inside of a joint through an arthroscope.
drawing in or out by suction; as in breathing objects into the respiratory tract or suctioning substances from a site.
unfocused refraction of light rays on the retina.
without any symptoms.
act of listening for sounds within the body, usually with a stethoscope, such as to evaluate the heart, lungs, intestines, or fetal heart tones.
from the Latin azote meaning nitrogen plusemia, meaning blood; the condition of having excessive amounts of nitrogen in the blood.
the science and study of bacteria.
equality between the debit and credit sides of an accounting equation; that which is left over after additions and subtractions have been made to an account; remainder; amount due.
noun, a soft material applied to a body part to hold a dressing in place, immobilize a body part, or aid in controlling bleeding; verb, to apply a wrapping material for treatment.
not cancerous or malignant.

the dissolved form of carbon dioxide; it combines with water to make carbonic acid, H<font face="LWWSUB" size="10">2</font>CO<font face="LWWSUB" size="10">3</font>. Carbonic acid loses one of its hydrogen (H) ions to then form bicarbonate, HCO<font face="LWWSUB" size="10">3</font><font face="LWWSUP" size="10">-</font>.
bilirubin in the urine.
a collection of fluid in or beneath the epidermis; a vesicle.
heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute.
describing medication administered between the cheek and gum of the mouth.
large blister or vesicle.
infection of interconnected group of hair follicles or several furuncles forming a mass.
enlarged heart muscle.
any disease affecting the myocardium.
progressive loss of transparency of the lens of the eye, resulting in opacity and loss of sight.
the most basic unit of all living organisms.
yellowish or brownish waxlike secretion in the external ear canal; earwax.
a hard ulcer that appears two to three weeks after exposure to syphilis, near the site of infection.
long-standing.
explanation; removal of confusion or uncertainty.
the study of the blood's ability to clot.
the act of compelling or forcing someone to do something that they do not want to do.
suturing of the vagina.
visual examination of the vagina and cervix under magnification.
injury to the brain due to trauma.
protection of patient data from unauthorized personnel.
an agreement between a patient and physician to do a given medical procedure.
situation or condition that prohibits the prescribing or administering of a drug or medication.
sudden, involuntary muscle contraction of voluntary muscle group.
any of the hormonal steroid substances obtained from the adrenal cortex.
a naturally occurring steroidal hormone that regulates metabolism and acts as an anti-inflammatory agent.
A breakdown product of creatine, which aids in delivering energy to cells.
severe congenital hypothyroidism; signs include dwarfism, low intelligence, puffy features, dry skin, macroglossia, and poor muscle tone.
the surgical destruction of tissue using freezing temperature with liquid nitrogen or carbon dioxide.

a laboratory process whereby microorganisms are grown in a special medium often for the purpose of identifying a causative agent in an infectious disease; also means the way of life, including commonly held beliefs, of a group of people.
Study of the microscopic structure of cells.
substance that reduces congestion or swelling.
the act of swallowing.
separation or opening of the edges of a wound.
progressive organic mental deterioration with loss of intellectual function.
the main component of the tooth structure, surrounds the inner pulp and lies just below the enamel.
fungal infection of the skin.
clearing of drugs from the body and treating the withdrawal symptoms.
the condition of having the heart in the right side of the thoracic cavity.
a disorder of metabolism characterized by polyuria and polydipsia; caused by a deficiency in ADH or an inability of the kidneys to respond to ADH.
identification of a disease or condition by evaluating physical signs and symptoms, health history, and laboratory tests; a disease or condition identified in a person.

removal of waste in blood not filtered by kidneys by passing fluid through a semipermeable barrier that allows normal electrolytes to remain, either with a machine with circulatory access or by passing a balanced fluid through the peritoneal cavity.
relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle.
making a difference in favor of or against someone.
definite pathological process having a distinctive set of symptoms and course of progression.
killing or rendering inert most but not all pathogenic microorganisms.
one who contributes something to another.
any substance that may modify one or more of the functions of an organism.
the act of compelling or forcing someone to do something that they do not want to do.

abnormal underdevelopment of the body with extreme shortness but normal proportions; achondroplastic dwarfism is an inherited growth disorder characterized by shortened limbs and a large head but almost normal trunk proportions.
inability to swallow or difficulty in swallowing.
impairment of voice; hoarseness.
characteristic black and blue mark that results from blood as it accumulates under the skin.
superficial dermatitis.
tracing of the electrical activity of the brain.
a person hired to perform given duties in return for financial compensation.
A physician who specializes in disorders of the endocrine system.
chemicals that are often called the body's "natural painkillers" that tend to produce a euphoria, or "good feeling." Release of endorphins is often caused by physical movement or exercise.
bed wetting.
redness of the skin.
a red blood cell.
cause of disease.
a feeling of well-being
the process of indicating how well the patient or person is progressing toward a particular goal; to appraise; to determine the worth or quality of something or someone.
abnormal protrusion of the eyeballs.
outside of the cell.
outside the eye, as in extraocular eye movement.
having above-normal body temperature.
in communication, the response to input from another.
grouping of data that is given a name for easy access.
special x-ray technique for examining a body part by immediate projection onto a fluorescent screen.
inflammation of hair follicles.
manner or style of walking.
chemical that kills most pathogenic microorganisms; disinfectant.
excessive size and stature caused most frequently by hypersecretion of the human growth hormone (HGH).
abnormal increase in the fluid in the eye, usually as a result of obstructed outflow, resulting in degeneration of the intraocular components and blindness.
an enlargement of the thyroid gland.
the percentage of red blood cells in whole blood.
the study of blood and blood-forming tissues.
blood clot that forms at an injury site.
decrease in the volume of plasma in blood causing an increase in blood components. Can be caused by excessive application of the tourniquet.
the functioning unit of the red blood cell.
rupture of erythrocytes with the release of hemoglobin into the plasma or serum causing the specimen to appear pink or red in color.
referring to traits or disorders that are transmitted from parent to offspring.
protrusion of an organ through the muscle wall of the cavity that normally surrounds it.
substance found normally in the body in response to injured cells, producing the inflammatory process: dilation of capillaries, increased gastric secretions, contraction of smooth muscles.
study of the microscopic structure of tissue.
referring to an alternative type of medicine in which patients are treated with small doses of substances that produce similar symptoms and use the body's own healing abilities.
a substance that is produced by an endocrine gland and travels through the blood to a distant organ or gland where it acts to modify the structure or function of that gland or organ.
an excessive amount of calcium in the blood.
an increase in blood sugar, as in diabetes mellitus.
excessive proliferation of normal cells in the normal tissue arrangement of an organism.
abnormally deep, gasping breaths
morbidly high blood pressure.
a respiratory rate that greatly exceeds the body's oxygen demands.
deficiency of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
part of the diencephalon; activates and controls the peripheral nervous system, endocrine system, and certain involuntary functions.
below-normal body temperature.
visual examination with magnification of the uterus.
act or process of rendering an individual immune to specific disease.
the study of antigen-antibody reactions.
highly infectious skin infection causing erythema and progressing to honey-colored crusts.
inability to achieve or maintain an erection.
inability to control elimination, either urine or feces or both.
invasion by disease-producing microorganisms.
leakage of intravenous fluids into surrounding tissues.

a statement of approval from the patient for the physician to perform a given procedure after the patient has been educated about the risks and benefits of the procedure; also referred to as expressed consent.
pertaining to the regions of the groin.
effects, positive or negative, of two or more drugs taken by a patient.
occurring at intervals.
inside of the cell.
skin condition characterized by overgrowth and thickening.
abnormally deep dorsal curvature of the thoracic spine; also known as humpback or hunchback.
involuntary contractions of the uterine muscle resulting in cervical dilation and effacement (thinning) of the cervix; prelude to childbirth.
a place where research, investigation, or scientific testing takes place.
process of viewing the internal abdominal cavity and its contents through a specialized endoscope.
incision of the abdominal cavity.
surgical removal of the larynx.
a white blood cell
abnormal increase of leukocytes (white blood cells).
a flexible band of tissue that holds joints together.
the descent of the fetus in the pelvis.
a substance made up of a lipid and a protein.
uterine discharge following childbirth, composed of some blood, mucus and tissue.
agent that reduces friction.
a type of leukocyte.
a monocyte that has left the circulation and settled and matured in tissue; macrophages process antigens and present them to T-cells, activating the immune specific response.
imaging technique that uses a strong magnetic field.
media.spanishterm: im<font face="LWWSYM">[</font>genes por resonancia magn<font face="LWWSYM">e</font>tica

media.def: cancerous.
skillful use of the hands in diagnostic procedures.
dark pigment that gives color to the skin, hair and eyes.
black, tarry stools caused by digested blood from the gastrointestinal tract.
membranes of the spinal cord and brain.
the curved upper surface of a liquid in a container.
excessive bleeding during menstruation.
words sent from one person to another; information sent through spoken, written, or body language.
sum of chemical processes that result in growth, energy production, elimination of waste, and body functions performed as digested nutrients are distributed.
the study of pathogen identification and antibiotic susceptibility determination.
microscopic living organisms.
type of severe headache, usually unilateral; may appear in cluster
inflammation of the myocardial layer of the heart.
the middle layer of the walls of the heart, composed of cardiac muscle.
nearsightedness.
incision into the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure.
performance of an act that a reasonable health care worker would not have done or the omission of an act that a reasonable person would have done.
abnormal growth of new tissue; tumor.
placement of a catheter in the kidney pelvis to drain urine from an obstructed kidney.
the study of food and how it is used for growth, nourishment, and repair.
excision of an ovary.
describing medication instilled into the eye
physician who specializes in treatment of disorders of the eyes.
lighted instrument used to examine the inner surfaces of the eye.
specialist who can measure for errors of refraction and prescribe lenses but who cannot treat diseases of the eye or perform surgery.
the source or starting point; (muscle) any part that is made up of cells and tissues that cause it to perform its specified function in conjunction with a body system.
the source or starting point; (muscle) the more fixed end of a muscle, usually the proximal end.
abnormal porosity of the bone, most often found in the elderly, predisposing the affected bony tissue to fracture
physician who specializes in treatment of diseases and disorders of the ears, nose, and throat.
instrument used for visual examination of the ear canal and tympanic membrane.
the periodic rupture of the mature ovum from the ovary.
feeling of an increased heart rate or pounding heart that may be felt during an emotional response or a cardiac disorder.
the part of the autonomic nervous system involved in periods free from stress.
disease-causing microorganisms.
physician who specializes in the care of infants, children, and adolescents.
specialty of medicine that deals with the care of infants, children and adolescents.
infestation with parasitic lice.
striking with the hands to evaluate the size, borders, consistency, and presence of fluid or air.
inflammation of the sac that covers the heart.
pertaining to or situated away from the center.
study of how drugs act within the body.
study of the action of drugs within the body from administration to excretion.
study of drugs and their origin, nature, properties, and effects upon living organisms.

an inert substance given as a medicine for its suggestive effect; an inert compound identical in appearance to material being tested in experimental research, which may or may not be known to the physician and/or patient, administered to distinguish between drug action and suggestive effect of the material under study.

the serous membrane enclosing the lungs; (visceral pleura: the layer that covers the lungs most closely; parietal pleura: the layer that follows the contours and lines the chest wall, the diaphragm, and the mediastinum).
a fold of skin that forms a cover.
substance that delays decomposition.
a series of steps required to perform a given task; a medical service or test that is coded for reimbursement.
Prevention of development of disease or condition.
any artificial replacement for a missing body part, such as false teeth or an artificial limb.
physician who specializes in radiology; performs some procedures and interprets images to provide diagnostic information.
branch of medicine including diagnostic and therapeutic applications of x-rays.
pertaining to the rectum and vagina.
correcting a fracture by realigning the bones; may be closed (corrected by manipulation) or open (requires surgery).
a return or backward flow of fluid.
bending of light rays that enter the pupil to reflect exactly on the fovea centralis, the area of greatest visual acuity.
body's immune response to prevent infections by invading pathogenic microorganisms.
virus containing reverse transcriptase, which allows the viral cell to replicate its DNA in the DNA of the host cell, thereby taking over the substance of the cell.
small, pointed knife with a convex edge for surgical procedures.
use of chemical agents to treat esophageal varices to produce fibrosis and hardening of the tissue.
lateral curve of the spine, usually in the thoracic area, with a corresponding curve in the lumbar region, causing uneven shoulders and hips.
susceptibility to a certain substance.
medical interventions completed by a provider.
lack of oxygen to individual cells of the body.
instrument that enlarges and separates the opening of a cavity to expose its interior for examination.
device used to immobilize a sprain, strain, fracture, or dislocated limb.
bacterial life form that resists destruction by heat, drying, or chemicals. Spore-producing bacteria include botulism and tetanus.
process, act, or technique for destroying microorganisms using heat, water, chemicals, or gases.
inflammation of the mucous membranes of the mouth.
a factor that induces body tension; can be positive or negative.
beneath the skin.
describing medication administered under the tongue
temporary removal of privileges.
the part of the autonomic nervous system involved in stress reaction.
subjective indications of disease or bodily dysfunction as sensed by the patient.
sudden fall in blood pressure or cerebral hypoxia resulting in loss of consciousness.
a collection of organs that perform a certain function.
contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
heart rate of more than 100 beats per minute.
use of computed imaging and information systems to transmit diagnostic images to distant locations.
tough, flexible fibers that bind muscle to bone.
a hemolytic anemia caused by deficient hemoglobin synthesis; more commonly found in those of Mediterranean heritage.
having to do with treating or curing disease; curative.
excess quantities of thyroid hormone in the tissues.
procedure in which the x-ray tube and film move in relation to each other during exposure, blurring out all structures except those in the focal plane.
a small mass of lymphoid tissue; includes the palatine, nasopharyngeal and lingual tonsils.
The study of the presence and measurement of drugs in the blood.
toxin treated to destroy its toxicity but still capable of inducing formation of antibodies.
permanent surgical stoma in the neck with an indwelling tube.
passage of light through body tissues for the purpose of examination.
a device of pressing against a hernia to keep it in place.
imaging technique that uses sound waves to diagnose or monitor various body structures.
each part of a name or title that is used in indexing; a quantity of a standard measurement.
the pair of tubes designed to carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder.
surgical opening to the outside of the body from the ureter to facilitate drainage of urine from an obstructed kidney.
the short tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body.
a by-product of protein metabolism present in the blood and excreted by the kidneys.
examination of the physical, chemical, and microscopic properties of urine.
hives.
suspension of infectious agents or some part of them, given to establish resistance to an infectious disease.
wart.
sensation of whirling of oneself or the environment; dizziness.
skin lesion that appears as a small sac containing fluid; a blister.
capable of growing and living.
the science and study of viruses.
a paperless system or chart on your computer.
a harmful invader that can damage your computer.
invisible electromagnetic radiation waves used in diagnosis and treatment of various disorders.
